definition: Something, like pollen, dust, mold, or animal dander, that causes a reaction in your body, such as a rash or sneezing.
Something that is used to treat, manage, or prevent medical conditions.
Chest pain or discomfort that you feel when there is not enough blood flowing to your heart.
A long-term disease that leads the airways to your lungs to swell, making it hard to breathe.
A drug that reduces pain or that puts you to sleep as during surgery.
Medicines that help blood flow smoothly without blood clots.
A blood clot that forms in a vein deep in your body.
A blood clot that forms in a vein deep in your body.
A treatment that does the work of your kidneys when they can"t.
An abnormal reaction of the immune system to natural, rubber latex.
High blood pressure
Giving a person a vaccine to protect them against a disease.
A severe reaction to certain drugs used to reduce pain or put you to sleep (ie. anesthesia).
Medicine; substances used to treat, manage, or prevent medical conditions.
Any kind of illness that can affect your mood, thinking, or how you act.
A doctor.
An order from your doctor, nurse, or physician assistant for drugs or other treatment.
When a blood clot blocks in an artery in your lung suddenly.
Another doctor who redirected you to get a second opinion.
When you stop breathing for 10 seconds or more when you sleep.
A gland in your neck that is shaped like a butterfly. It makes hormones that help your body work normally.
2-letter code at the end of the health number on an Ontario Health Card.
Workplace Safety and Insurance Board
